fields.headline: Lords and plebs
fields.bodyText: If elected MPs can be sacked by the electorate, why can't unelected peers be sacked by MPs (Report, February 8)? If all peers were sacked en masse, it would clear the decks for a democratically elected second chamber. They might enjoy release from their Gilbert and Sullivan antics. I was sacked by my constituents from the House of Commons twice and found my new found freedom immensely enjoyable on each occasion. Christopher Price London A matter of such constitutional importance as Lords reform should require a referendum of the electorate. Let the plebs decide their lordships' fate. John Hartley Kirkby Lonsdale, Lancs I heard Tony Blair say, on Radio 4's Today programme last Friday, he'd been pleased to "lead" the British people. Isn't the verb, in a democracy, to "serve"? Jason Ditton Glasgow Spare a thought for those of us with birthdays on Valentine's Day ('We can fit you in after 10pm', G2, February 7). Securing a table for more than two is a major feat and, if you do, trying to enjoy a raucous night out with friends or even taking your daughter along with your husband invites confused if not hostile looks from other diners. And your favourite dishes at your local eatery are shoved off the menu. Val Glenny Sheffield If Eddie Askew (Letters, February 6) is in search of a purpose for 35mm film canisters, he need look no further than the Whitechapel Mission - whitechapel.org.uk - who use them for individual portions of toiletries. They also have a list of other items they require. Caroline Kirkup Wingrave, Buckinghamshire Our wallcharts (Letters, January 30) came with us to Nepal, on a trek to Poon Hill (3,210m), and were closely examined in every village we passed through. Lynn Rankin Preston, Lancashire February 2: wasps in Edinburgh (Letters, February 8). February 8: snow on my Ludlow lawn. The world's upside down. Robin Bennett Ludlow, Shropshire
